title: First step towards a Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance
text: In 1925, the sovereign approved a constitutional article authorizing the Confederation to sketch an Old-age and survivors' insurance (AHV). The template is not a comprehensive breakthrough, but rather the result of a precarious compromise. Especially in the delicate question of financing, the article remains vague.

title: Social security on the defensive
text: The global economic crisis is leading to social emergencies in various areas in Switzerland. However, the political forces are divided over the appropriate crisis management. First, the cities are responding with the expansion of social care. The Confederation catches up late to deal actively with unemployment.

title: During the war: towards innovation or stagnation in social policy?
text: Unlike the First, the Second World War embodies a development thrust for social security. The most visible sign is the introduction of a wage and earnings order and after the war, the founding of the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance (AHV). However, the progress regarding the expansion of the welfare state remains modest and limited.

title: The Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance: Centerpiece of social security
text: In his 1944 New Year's speech, Federal Councilor Stampfli announces with a big media response the rapid establishment of a state pension scheme. Three years later, on July 6th, 1947, the voters adopted the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance (AHV) legislation; At the beginning of 1948, the first pensions will be paid out. The AHV quickly becomes the symbol of the Swiss welfare state par excellence.

title: Blocked expansion of health insurance
text: Unlike the progress of establishing the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance (AHV), the health insurance legislation stagnates after the Second World War. The modest proposal for a Federal Tuberculosis Insurance does not find favor with the urn at all. Further concerns, such as a national mandatory health insurance, are therefore off the table.
Message of the Federal Council to the Federal Assembly concerning the support of schools for social work (of October 17th, 1952).

title: Invalidity: insurance and integration instead of social assistance
text: In the late 1950ies, the time has come for the introduction of the Federal Invalidity Insurance (IV). Although modestly equipped, it closes an important gap in the social security system and is committed to an innovative principle: «integration before retirement».

title: Social Casework and Social Subsistence Minimum: Modernization of Social Welfare
text: After 1960, many cantons reformed their social assistance approaches. The motto is now «Helping people help themselves». The models for the innovations, such as the social case work, originate mainly from the USA.
Federal Council's message to the Federal Assembly on a federal decree extending the deadline for implementing institutional reforms under the Criminal Code (dated March 20th, 1961).

title: Towards a minimal wage in old-age provision care
text: The pensions of the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance (AHV) and the Federal invalidity Insurance (IV) are well below the subsistence level in the 1960ies. Many retirees continue to suffer from poverty. For them, supplementary benefits are introduced in 1965. At the same time, this reduces the pressure to further expand state pension provision.

title: Introduction of the residence principle in social assistance
text: Until the 1970ies, impoverished citizens can be turned away from their place of residence and transferred to their community of citizenship. In 1975, this relic is finally abolished. Now, all the impoverished have the full freedom of establishment.

title: Reacting to the economic crisis: reorganization of the unemployment insurance
text: In response to the recession of 1974-75, Switzerland introduces a federal mandatory unemployment insurance scheme. The implementation, however, is dragging on. Finally, in 1984 a definitive solution comes into effect.

title: First step towards a Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance
text: The focus of the Independent Expert Commission's (IEC) investigations is on recent modern history, specifically, the period commencing around the year 1930 and continuing up to 1981. In 1981, seven years after Switzerland's ratification of the European Human Rights Convention, the legal procedures for ordering involuntary commitment were incorporated into the Swiss Civil Code. While public authorities were still permitted under those provisions to institutionalise individuals against their will and for their own safety, the new statutes established conditions applicable nationwide for ordering such a major infringement of an individual's basic rights. Prior to the adoption of the federal provisions on involuntary commitment, the rules on administrative detention in almost all of the cantons failed, with few exceptions, to provide for any judicial appeals process in such cases.
